case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Shoorji Vallabhdas and Co.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court by Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay against Bombay High Court judgment dated October 1, 1958 on certificate under section 66A(2) of Indian Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal on a certificate of fitness under section 66A 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act by the High Court of Bombay, against its judgment dated October 1, 1958.

facts.text: Assessment year 1948-49 corresponding to previous year ending March 31, 1948

anchor.surface_text: We are concerned with the assessment year 1948-49, corresponding to the previous year ending March 31, 1948.

facts.text: Assessee firm consisted of three partners: Shoorji Vallabhdas and his two sons Pratapsinh and Vikramsinh

anchor.surface_text: The assessee firm consisted of three partners, Shoorji Vallabhdas and his two sons, Pratapsinh and Vikramsinh.

facts.text: Assessee firm was managing agents of Malabar Steamship Co. Ltd. and New Dholera Steamships Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee firm was the managing agents of several shipping companies including the Malabar Steamship Co. Ltd., and the New Dholera Steamships Ltd.

facts.text: Agreement with Malabar Steamship Co. Ltd. on September 16, 1938 modified on December 7, 1943

anchor.surface_text: With the Malabar Steamship Co. Ltd. the assessee firm had entered into an agreement on September 16, 1938 modified on December 7, 1943

facts.text: Agreement with New Dholera Steamships Ltd. on June 8, 1946

anchor.surface_text: , and with the New Dholera Steamships Ltd. on June 8, 1946.

facts.text: Under agreements, assessee firm entitled to 10% of freight as commission

anchor.surface_text: Under these agreements, the assessee firm was entitled to receive as its commission, 10 per cent. of the freight charged.

facts.text: Between April 1, 1947 and December 31, 1947, commission Rs. 1,71,885 from Malabar Steamship Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Between April 1, 1947, and December 31, 1947, the amount of commission at the rate of 10 per cent. of the freight was Rs. 1,71,885 from the Malabar Steamship Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Between April 1, 1947 and December 31, 1947, commission Rs. 2,56,815 from New Dholera Steamships Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: and Rs. 2,56,815 from the New Dholera Steamships Ltd. These amounts were credited in the books of account of the assessee firm to itself

facts.text: Amounts credited in books of assessee firm to itself with debit to shipping companies

anchor.surface_text: These amounts were credited in the books of account of the assessee firm to itself with a corresponding debit to the shipping companies.

facts.text: In 1947, assessee firm floated two private limited companies: Shoorji Vallabhdas Ltd. and Pratapsingh Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: In 1947, the assessee firm floated two private limited companies, called Shoorji Vallabhdas Ltd. and Pratapsingh Ltd.

facts.text: On November 20, 1947, assessee firm expressed desire to resign managing agency and appoint the two new companies on same terms

anchor.surface_text: The assessee firm desired to substitute these two companies as the managing agents of the shipping companies, one for each, and on November 20, 1947, expressed its desire to resign from the managing agency

facts.text: On November 27, 1947, two shareholders of Malabar Steamship Co. Ltd. objected to commission rate

anchor.surface_text: Two shareholders of the Malabar Steamship Co. Ltd. objected to the rate of commission, and wrote a letter on November 27, 1947, in protest.

facts.text: Assessee firm offered voluntary reduction of managing agency commission to 2.5% of total freight for current and future years

anchor.surface_text: That whilst we will continue to insist on our right to receive the full managing commission, however, in order to put the company on a firm financial basis, and because we are interested both as shareholders and managing agents in the prosperity of the company, we shall voluntarily agree to a reduction in the managing agency commission both in respect of the current year as also in future years as may be mutually agreed between the board and ourselves or between the company and ourselves to the extent of 2 1/2 per cent of the total freight.

facts.text: Similar procedure followed for New Dholera Steamships Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: A similar procedure was followed in the case of the New Dholera Steamships Ltd., though all the documents are not in the record.

facts.text: On December 30, 1947, extraordinary general meetings held, two private companies appointed managing agents from January 1, 1948

anchor.surface_text: On December 30, 1947, extraordinary general meetings of the two managed companies were held, and the two private limited companies were appointed as the managing agents from January 1, 1948.

facts.text: Assessee firm's offer to reduce commission was accepted

anchor.surface_text: It appears, therefore, that the offer contained in the letter of the assessee firm was accepted.

facts.text: At annual general meetings in December 1948, commission reduced from 10% to 2.5% of freight

anchor.surface_text: Later, at the annual general meetings of the two managed companies held in December, 1948, the commission was reduced from 10 per cent. of the freight to 2 1/2 per cent. as already agreed.

facts.text: Assessee firm gave up Rs. 1,36,903 from Malabar Steamship Co. Ltd. and Rs. 2,00,625 from New Dholera Steamships Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: As a result, the assessee firm gave up 75 per cent. of its earnings during the relevant years of account, which amounted to Rs. 1,36,903 Malabar Steamship Co. Ltd.  and Rs. 2,00,625  New Dholera Steamships Ltd. .

facts.text: Income-tax Officer and Appellate Assistant Commissioner held larger commission accrued and assessable, disallowed claim under section 10(2)(xv)

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment which followed, the Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner came to the conclusion that the amount of larger commission had already accrued during the previous year ending March 31, 1948, and was thus assessable. The amount given up was also claimed by the assessee firm as an expenditure under section 10 2  xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act, but was disallowed.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal President held no accrual or receipt of larger income, reduced assessment

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the Appellate Tribunal, the Accountant Member was of the opinion that the appeal should be rejected. The Judicial Member, however, took the opposite view. The case was then laid before the President, who agreed with the Judicial Member. According to the President, even though the actual reduction took place after the year of account was over, there was, in fact, an agreement to reduce the commission even during the currency of the account year, and the larger income neither accrued nor was received by the assessee firm. In accordance with the opinion of the President, the assessment was reduced by deleting the extra commission from the computation.

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered first referred question in negative: sums not income of previous year

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the view of the President, and answered the first question in the negative, and declined to answer the second.

facts.text: Commissioner contended larger income accrued in previous year, was assessable, arrangement was voluntary gift, books on mercantile basis

anchor.surface_text: The contentions before us  as also in the High Court  were that the income had already accrued to the assessee firm in the year of account, and was thus assessable, that the arrangement amounted to a voluntary gift by the assessee firm to the shipping companies, and that the books being kept on a mercantile basis showed the commission as each amount of freight was entered.

facts.text: Supreme Court held larger income neither accrued nor received by assessee firm

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was right in coming to the conclusion that on the facts of this case the larger income neither accrued nor was received by the assessee firm.
section 66A 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act by the High Court of Bombay, against its judgment dated October 1, 1958.

holdings.text: Income tax is a levy on income

anchor.surface_text: Income tax is a levy on income. No doubt, the Income-tax Act takes into account two points of time at which the liability to tax is attracted, viz., the accrual of the income or its receipt

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fundamental principle that tax applies only to actual income, not hypothetical

holdings.text: if income does not result at all, there cannot be a tax, even though in book-keeping, an entry is made about a hypothetical income which does not materialize

anchor.surface_text: if income does not result at all, there cannot be a tax, even though in book-keeping, an entry is made about a hypothetical income which does not materialize.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance over form: accrual or receipt points secondary to actual income resulting; book entries insufficient

holdings.text: Where income has, in fact, been received and is subsequently given up in such circumstances that it remains the income of the recipient, even though given up, the tax may be payable. Where, however, the income can be said not to have resulted at all, there is obviously neither accrual nor receipt of income

anchor.surface_text: Where income has, in fact, been received and is subsequently given up in such circumstances that it remains the income of the recipient, even though given up, the tax may be payable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes cases of post-receipt relinquishment (taxable) from no-result at all (non-taxable)

holdings.text: A mere book-keeping entry cannot be income, unless income has actually resulted, and in the present case, by the change of the terms the income which accrued and was received consisted of the lesser amounts and not the larger

anchor.surface_text: A mere book-keeping entry cannot be income, unless income has actually resulted, and in the present case, by the change of the terms the income which accrued and was received consisted of the lesser amounts and not the larger.

holdings.text: This was not a gift by the assessee firm to the managed companies. The reduction was a part of the agreement entered into by the assessee firm to secure a long-term managing agency arrangement for the two companies which it had floated

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arrangement contractual for business purpose, not voluntary gift after accrual
